messages: 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (20:55): Hixie: HTML5 says data: URIs have no domain; spec says that document.domain must then be null, but postMessage doesn't quite say how "has no domain" maps to the |domain| attribute on the dispatched event -- is it likewise null, or is it the empty string?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:56): Real pre-ISO-8859-1, pre-HTTP 1.0 Web content: http://montaasi.tky.fi/vanha/johtis/vanhat/1957/Kokous-27.09.1957.txt
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:02): hmm. I need a non-disruptive way to trigger reflow in Gecko from JS
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:03): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33, the URI itself?

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (21:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: a document contained in a data: URL uses postMessage -- what's the value of the domain attribute on the event the receiver will get, null or ""?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:11): oh wait, data: doesn't have a domain so it can't be itself
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:11): dunno
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:11): haven't tested that
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (21:15): it's super-edge-case, but I'm implementing it now and can do either way -- figure I should do it right the first time
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:21): do you have a test using document.postMessage() ?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:21): i could test in Opera
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:40): I'm sufficiently confused now
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:40): http://blogs.msdn.com/cwilso/archive/2008/01/22/i-feel-happy-too.aspx#7202711
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:40): so...the IE version lock-in only applies for HTML4 / XHTML1 doctypes?
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:40): which means HTML5 can proceed using the latest (most standards-compliant) mode of IE?
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (21:41): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: sec, I'll write something up

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:43): 62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e: Apparently so, though it's kind of hard to tell yet since Microsoft hasn't been giving out many details and people have to try to piece together random blog comments to work out how it works...

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (21:43): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: data:text/html,<script>window.onload%20=%20function()%20{%20document.addEventListener("message",%20function(e)%20{%20alert("domain:%20"%20+%20e.domain%20+%20",%20type:%20"%20+%20(typeof%20e.domain));%20},%20false);%20window.postMessage("foo");%20};</script>
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:43): yeah, kinda ridiculous
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:43): they need to publish a technical document
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:44): that seems like kind of a big detail to leave out
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:44): I think it's the difference between me caring a lot and not caring at all

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:44): If <!doctype not-html-4-or-xhtml-1> gets maximum-standards-support, that would prevent much of the criticism that they've been getting, so it does seem odd to have not mentioned it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:47): -> mtg
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:09): I love half the comments on the IE blog post. "Opt-in to standards? Never!" while assuming the current doctype switch is a standard.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:20): anyone know when unicode support was added into Python?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:24): 2.0, seemingly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:25): What counts as "support"?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:30): I mean in having a native Unicode string type
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:33): adds ieparsehack.js to his web page

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:47): http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3Cbody%3E%0D%0A%3Cscript%3Edocument.createElement('bar')%3C%2Fscript%3E%0D%0A%3Cbar%2F%3Ex%3Cbar%3Ey%3C%2Fbar%3Ez%3C%2Fbar%3E
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (22:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, what does it do? Change the render mode between IE7 and IE8 every 0.5 seconds?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:48): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Is the first bar supposed to be self-closing?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:50): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: was that meant to me?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:50): well, it is in ie
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:50): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33, empty string in Opera
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:51): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: Well, it's <bar/>, then <bar></bar> and finally an unmatched </bar> right now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:51): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33, sorry for the delay, had a meeting and window.postMessage() does not work in Opera; we use document.postMessage()
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:51): are you planning on supporting both eventually, then?
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:52): we currently return an empty string, for what that's worth
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:52): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: my point is that createElement() causes ie to use "xml parsing" for that tag name, same as tags that have colons in them
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:52): ok, that's the same then
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:52): i.e. /> is self-closing, unlike for "html parsing"
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:53): too bad we can't have the same behavior for both
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:53): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: Aren't all unknown elements self-closing by default in IE?
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:53): dunno how much a compatibility concern it'd be to make both null, since changing document.domain is risky-ish
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:54): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33, does the domain value do what document.domain does?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:54): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33, I don't think there's content out there that relies on it being "" so that should be changeable
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:54): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: Yeah, but the issue is making the new elements work in IE, isn't it? And those don't have colons
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:54): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: no, data:text/html,<script>alert(document.domain)</script> alerts null for me while the previous was empty string
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:55): that's the empty string in Opera
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:55): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: yep. *but*, integration of svg and mathml has been discussed, with /> syntax
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:55): thank god
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:55): we're internally consistent :p
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:56): tries Safari
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:56): Safari does empty string too it seems
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:57): data:text/html,<script>alert(document.domain === "")</script> yields true anyway
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:57): hopes Firefox can change
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:57): guess Hixie may want to reconsider null vs. empty string
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:57): I can certainly change postMessage
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:58): document.domain, probably as well
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:58): shouldn't be hard, question is whether it breaks people
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (22:58): would hope not
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:00): they'd rely on non-standards!
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:00): can you imagine?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:01): But they aren't MS, so no need to do much.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:01): ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2: It just calls document.createElement('header') etc
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (23:02): Seriously, I wonder whether changing the value of the <meta> element after-the-fact works
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:02): ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2: it won't, the action is done when the parser comes across it
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (23:04): that's no fun
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:05): Or at least that's the impression I got from Chris Wilson when talking to him about it over a month ago in #html-wg
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:07): I wonder how nicely it will interact with the Live DOM Viewer's method of dynamically constructing pages...
